note: An empirical description of vertical FDI patterns based on multinationals operating in the United States.
title: Firms in International Trade
A nontechnical description of empirical patterns of trade at the firm level that focuses on U.S
Importers, Exporters, and Multinationals: A Portrait of Firms in the US that Trade Goods
Producer Dynamics: New Evidence from Micro Data
A nontechnical description of empirical patterns of trade at the firm level that focuses on U.S
Integration of Trade and Disintegration of Production in the Global Economy
A description of how the supply chain has been broken up into many processes that are then performed in different locations
Vertical Production Networks in Multinational Firms
Elements of Multinational Strategy
A recent textbook focused on multinationals
Trade, FDI, and the Organization of Firms
A technical survey of recent research on models that incorporate firm performance differences, and on multinationals and outsourcing
Understanding Global Trade
A nontechnical book that covers both comparative advantage theories of trade and more recent theories of trade based on the firm
Market Structure and Foreign Trade
A technical presentation of monopolistic competition and other models of trade with economies of scale
Monopolistic Competition in International Trade
A collection of papers representing many of the leading researchers in imperfect competition and international trade
The Boundaries of Multinational Enterprises and the Theory of International Trade
A nontechnical survey of models of trade and multinationals
The Happy Few: The Internationalisation of European Firms: New Facts Based on Firm-Level Evidence
On the Equivalence of Tariffs and Quotas
Trade, Growth, and the Balance of Payments
The classic comparison of tariffs and quotas under monopoly
The Theory of Protection
A general survey of the effects of tariffs, quotas, and other trade policies
Regulating the Automobile
Contains an analysis of the most famous of all voluntary export restraints

note: trade policies in 21 different sectors.
title: Measuring the Costs of Protection in the United States
An assessment of U.S
Trade Restrictions as Facilitating Practices

A pioneering analysis of the effects of import quotas when both foreign and domestic producers have monopoly power, showing that the usual result is an increase in the profits of both groups—at consumers’ expense

container-title: U.S. International Trade Commission Staff Research Study 15
publisher: U.S. International Trade Commission. The Economic Effects of Significant U.S. Import Restraints
title: Measuring the Costs of Protection in Europe: European Commercial Policy in the 2000s
A survey of European trade policies and their effects, similar to Hufbauer and Elliot’s work for the United States
Calculating the Consumer and Net Welfare Costs of Import Relief
An exposition of the framework used in this chapter, with a description of how the framework is applied in practice to real industries
A regularly updated economic analysis of the effects of protection on the U.S
Trade Policy and Economic Welfare
The classic survey of economic arguments for and against protection
A comprehensive portrait of the real-world process of trade policy making, and its evolution over time
Interest Groups and Trade Policy
A collection of papers and case studies on modern political economy models of trade policy
The Uruguay Round: An Assessment
A mercifully brief and readable survey of the issues and accomplishments of the most recent GATT round, together with a survey of much of the relevant research
The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization
A comprehensive survey, with texts and other materials, of the legal framework of international trade
Understanding the WTO
A useful self-survey of the institution’s role and history
The Theory of Economic Development
A good example of the upbeat view taken of trade policies for economic development during the importsubstitution high tide of the 1950s and 1960s
Industry and Trade in Some Developing Countries
A key work in the emergence of a more downbeat view of import substitution in the 1970s and 1980s
The Chinese Economy: Transitions and Growth
A good overview of the radical changes in Chinese policy over time

note: How India shifted away from import substitution, and what happened as a result.
title: One Economics, Many Recipes
Views on trade and development from a leading skeptic of prevailing orthodoxies
Reintegrating India with the World Economy
Export Subsidies and International Market Share Rivalry
A basic reference on the potential role of subsidies as a tool of strategic trade policy
Can Labor Standards Improve Under Globalization?
A survey of the issues by an economist sympathetic to the cause of the activists
Fighting the Wrong Enemy: Antiglobalization Activists and Multinational Corporations
A survey of the issues by an economist less sympathetic to the activists
Trade Policy and Market Structure
A survey and synthesis of the literature on strategic trade policy and related topics
The Shipbreakers
A fascinating description of the shipbreaking industry of Alang and the dispute it has generated
International Monetary Fund, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, United Nations, and World Bank. System of National Accounts 2008
Definitive guidelines for constructing national income and product accounts

Applies a common methodology to construct international position data for a large sample of countries

title: In 1970, the foreign assets held by U.S. residents were equal in value to 6.2 percent of the U.S
capital stock (including residential housing
U.S.-owned assets abroad equaled about 56 percent of U.S. capital, while foreign assets in the United States had risen to about 66 percent of U.S. capital

note: capital stock. Moreover, the numbers in the previous paragraph describe total foreign assets, stocks and bonds alike, not just stocks, which alone represent claims on capital. What makes the
title: These percentages are much larger than those in 1970 but still seem too small. With full international portfolio diversification, we would expect them to reflect the size of the U.S. economy relative to that of the rest of the world. Thus, in a fully diversified world economy, something like 80 percent of the U.S. capital stock would be owned by foreigners, while U.S. residents’ claims on foreigners would equal around 80 percent of the value of the U.S
